actions.text:
See It Be It
•	Look around you and name something that you can see. For example, a tree or a cup
•	Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”
•	Countdown from 5 and make the shape of a tree with your bodies. Be as big and silly as possible.
•	Now let your child have a turn. What can they see?
•	If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside. 
•	When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!

Story time
•	Start the story with “Once upon a time there was a…”
•	Let your child make up the next sentence
•	Then you make up a sentence
•	Take turns until you have a wonderful new story
•	Make sure to end the story on a positive note.
•	Ask your child what was their favourite part of the story!

actions.text:
Superpowers
•	Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds. 
•	Ask your child “If you had the superpower to […] how would you use it?
•	Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out. 
•	Now let them choose a super power for you
•	Make sure you act it out too!

actions.text:
Three options
•	Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat or flying a plane
•	Say them to your child and ask, “Which would you prefer?”
•	Ask them why?
•	Now think of three more situations or ask your child to do it for you

actions.text:
Worms Go Home
•	Lie on your tummies and pretend your index fingers are a wiggly worm. 
•	With your other hand make a worm house by making a circle with your fingers and thumb and place it on the floor. 
•	Call out an instruction for your finger to touch, like “Worms on noses” or “Worms on ears”
•	When you call out “Worms go home”, your wiggly worm has to find a worm house as quickly as possible. 
•	The last worm to find a home calls out the instructions next. 
•	Keep playing until you feel rejuvenated from lying down.

When our children share something that is especially troubling, we need to remember to stay calm, listen, and be open.

Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
1. Take a deep breath before you respond. 
2. Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
3. Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?" 
4. Reassure your child that you are there for them. 
5. You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
6. Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action. 
7. Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.

Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.
Let your hand hang by your side. Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you relax your body.
Relax your arms and let your arms to swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out.
Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
Take a moment to reflect on your experience. Remember that you can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.

Mirror
•	This game can be played in pairs or even as a group
•	Stand facing each other or in a circle  
•	One person leads first while everyone else must copy, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.
•	Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.
•	After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead
•	Try it with no leaders!

Run Around and Do This 
•	Everyone runs around the room or garden.  Make sure the space is large enough and safe
•	At any time, someone can stop somewhere and say, “When you get over here, you do this!”

actions.text:
Blind Dragon 
•	This game is great if you have at least 4 people
•	Tell the story about a ferocious dragon who lived near a village. He would sneak into the village at night and steal people’s treasures – anything they loved.  Anybody who tried to take their treasure back would be eaten alive.  This continued for many years until the dragon became old, fat, and blind from sitting on his treasure and gazing at the glare of the gold coins. Then the townspeople could try and sneak into his lair and steal back their relatives’ treasure. 
•	One person plays the dragon. Dragon sits blindfolded or with eyes closed surrounded by a pile of treasure. 
•	Everyone has one piece of treasure that they must steal back. 
•	If the dragon hears you and points at you, you must go back to the starting place. 
•	Only one person can try to get the treasure at a time.

actions.text:
What Are You Doing? 
•	This game is best when more than 2 people play
•	One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner  
•	Another person asks, “What are you doing?”
•	The first person needs to say something that has nothing to do with combing hair, for example, “Tying my shoes.”  
•	The second person then starts pretending to tie their shoes until a new person asks, “What are you doing?” 
•	The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!

actions.text:
At the End of the Day
•	At the end of each day, take a minute to think about the day.  
•	Talk your child about one positive or fun thing they did.
•	Praise yourself for one thing you did well today.
•	Think of one thing that you are grateful for.  
•	You are a star!

actions.text:
Keep it positive! Make sure your children get lots of praise when they are behaving well. This will make them want to behave that way more often.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more.
We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.

Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves! 
Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:
Step 1. Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.
Step 2. Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'
Step 3. Praise with enthusiasm. Really mean it when you say it!
Praise your children when they are behaving well! They may not show it but you’ll see them doing that good behaviour again…

Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Try to find 3 things that you can praise your children for every day. You can also praise other adults in your household, too. Notice how they respond!

Invest in One-on-One Time! The more time you spend with your children, the more likely they will listen to you and behave well at other times. It really works!
Type "Y" if you want to learn more.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.

When we have difficult relationships with our teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.
The first 1000 days of life are a window of opportunity for your baby. It is when their brain develops faster than any other time in their life.
One-on-One Time with your children is free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and shows them that they are important. It also increases their confidence and self-esteem!
Then when our children are doing something quietly, we often heave a sigh of relief and leave them alone. But this is just when we need to “attend” to our children and to notice what they are doing.
When you spend time with your baby, you build a healthy attatchment between you both that will make them feel secure and loved.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

It is normal to struggle to think of what to do with our babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.

One-on-One Time with your teen helps build a positive and trusting relationship. When you really notice them and listen to what they are saying and what they like, you make them feel valued and appreciated.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child. Chat to you later!
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.
If you look closely and really attend to your baby, you will notice that they are communicating to you all the time in their own little way.

Here's how you can make One-on-One Time a success
1. Set aside time to spend with each child. It can be for just 5 minutes, or longer – it’s up to you. It can be at the same time each day so your children or teenagers can look forward to it.
Playing with your baby helps them develop and explore the world…

Here are some tips on how to make One-on-One Time a positive experience for you and your teen:
Here's how you can make One-on-One Time a success:

1. Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with your teen each day. Choose a time when you and our teen will not be interrupted and when your teen does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.
2. Switch off the TV and phone. This is virus-free time!

1. Try to spend time playing with your baby every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.

3. Ask your child what they would like to do. Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t OK with COVID-19 rules, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.

2. Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. Your teen might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!
2. Be close to your child. Skin-to-skin contact is especially important for new-borns and infants. For older toddlers, make sure you are at the same level as they are.
4. If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.
3. Give your teen all of your attention. Switch off the television and put away phones. Make sure you can give all of your attention to your teen.
3. Let things go at your child's pace. Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Remember that the world is brand new to your child!
5. If you cannot think of anything either, we are here to help! Just type "Play" and we will send you some activities to choose from.

4. Try to do something different than watching TV or playing with a tablet/phone. However, you may need to at first join your teen and watch their favourite TV programme with them. They may feel comfortable doing other activities with time.
Type "Play" for some suggestion of activities you can with your teen.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.
6. Try to follow your child's lead during One-on-One Time. Listen to and look at them. Accept their suggestions. And have fun!
4. Observe your child. See what facial expressions your child is making. What your child is interested in or looking at. Watch your child explore!

Congratulations! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Quality time with your children is the best gift that you can ever give them.

5. Listen to the sounds or words your child is making. Your child is learning to communicate. Listening to your child is more important than talking to them at this time. You can even make the same sounds by copying your child!

5. Try to follow your teen's lead during One-on-One Time. Accept their suggestions. Remember this is your teen's activity. There is no right or wrong during One-on-One Time. Your job is to show an interest and say something nice. And have fun!
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a siren, the feeling of a breeze, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on your child.

Create routines! Your children will feel more secure and safe when they know what is expected of them and how each day will go. Make a plan with them with time for play, meals, chores, school, and sleep.

Create a flexible but consistent daily routine. 
Make a schedule for you and your children that has time for structured activities as well as free time. Children or teenagers can help plan the routine for the day - like  making a studying timetable. Children will also follow this better if they help make it.

Having daily routines, such as mealtimes and bedtimes, can help create a stable environment for our children to feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security that they need to grow and develop.

Consistent rules, daily routines
They make a child feel secure and safe
From early morning until it’s bedtime
So they know how to behave

Involve your teen in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. They can plan when they do schoolwork and when they relax!
Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"

Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for young babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.

Here are some tips for how to help your child prepare for bedtime:
1. Try to have regular bedtimes each day as much as possible.
2. Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim. 
3. Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.
4. Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.

Be open to your children. They get stressed too - sometimes from different things from you. Allow them to express how they feel and accept their feelings. Try to listen to them and think about how it must feel for them
Type "Y" if you want to learn more.

Keep it positive. It normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."
Our children need attention! Attention is a powerful reward for most children, particularly when children are young.
Giving calm consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.
Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:

1. Identify the problem
2. Think of possible solutions. 
3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be.
4. Choose one solution 
5. Try it out!
6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.
If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.
Here are 4 tips for using consequences to help your child follow instructions or household rules:

Be open to your children's emotions. Your children will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
When we pay attention to negative behaviours, we teach our children to do more and more of the things we do not want them to do.
1. Give your child a choice to follow your instruction before giving them the consequence.
If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!
We can also teach our children the same steps.

When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems. 
Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.
2. Try to stay calm when giving the consequence.
When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.

These behaviours can take the form of whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child.

Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that redirecting your children only works before or at the beginning of a bad behaviour. 
You can also always type "Help" for more tips. Have a great day!
3. Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.
But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!

There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

Try to find solutions together:
1. Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings. 
2. Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective. 
3. Thank your teen for being open and trusting you
4. Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention – it is like an attention reward for bad behaviour. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way. This happens to all of us!

Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V. For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.
Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Helping your teen learn how to solve problems will be something they will take with them the rest of their lives. What a gift!
It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy.
For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum

Here are some examples of behaviours and possible consequences:
Fighting with siblings -> Take 1 minute pause in separate parts of the room
Talking rudely to elders -> Write a letter of apology
Using gadget over the limit -> No gadget use the next day

This may be especially the case for boys and men. But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.
Sound familiar? But there is an answer! We call it Ignore. And here are 4 steps on how to do it!
1. Try to redirect your child's attention to something new when they demand something from you or are trying to get negative attention.

Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Need to hold my hand for 10 minutes (kids)
Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Cannot see friends for a day (teen)
Refusing to put away toys -> Cannot play with them after dinner (or next hour)
2. If your child persists, ignore your child's behaviour. You could still be aware of what your child is doing while ignoring.

In summary, consequences should be...
1. Realistic: Consider the age of your child
2. Immediate: Give them as soon as possible
3. Fair: Make sure the consequence is not too harsh
4. Consistent: Make sure you can follow through if you have to
5. The last resort: Try to encourage the positive behaviour to happen more often!

Here are some tips for how we can communicate about emotions with our children, especially about difficult issues:
1. Accept your child’s feelings – even the difficult ones
2. Use words to describe how your child and you are feeling

Be open to your children's emotions. Your children will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.

There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy.

This may be especially the case for boys and men. But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.

Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

Here are some tips for how we can communicate about emotions with our children, especially about difficult issues:
1. Accept your child’s feelings – even the difficult ones
2. Use words to describe how your child and you are feeling
3. Be open and show your child that you hear what they are saying
4. Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved
5. It is okay for you to also feel difficult emotions about the same issues

actions.text:
Mirror
•	This game can be played in pairs or even as a group
•	Stand facing each other or in a circle  
•	One person leads first while everyone else must copy, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.
•	Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.
•	After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead
•	Try it with no leaders!

actions.text:
What Are You Doing? 
•	This game is best when more than 2 people play
•	One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner  
•	Another person asks, “What are you doing?”
•	The first person needs to say something that has nothing to do with combing hair, for example, “Tying my shoes.”  
•	The second person then starts pretending to tie their shoes until a new person asks, “What are you doing?” 
•	The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!

Crazy Chicken
•	Shake your left hands in the air 8 times while counting to 8 
•	Do it as fast and loud as you can
•	Repeat with your other hand. Repeat with both feet
•	Do it 7 times, then 6 times and continue until you get to 1.
•	Everyone calls out “Crazy chicken” and does their best crazy chicken dance!

actions.text:
Hello! How are you doing? We are so happy that you have signed up to receive these messages. It shows you care. 
Today's tip is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Children.

actions.value: Please choose one age group for these parenting tips. You might want to choose the child you are concerned about the most. You can always change this later by typing "Help" and selecting "Tech support"

actions.text: Hi! Have you spent 5 minutes or more of One-on-One Time with your children today?
Good for you! One-on-One Time shows your children that they are important to you. It really makes a difference!
Wonderful! Spending One-on-One Time with your children may make them more willing to help out more often. You are doing great!
Well done! One-on-One with your children gives you a chance to learn more about your their interests and abilities. You are a star!
Excellent job! One-on-One Time helps build a strong positive relationship between you and your children. Try to do it every day!
Thank you for making the effort to show your children that they are loved and valued. You deserve a gold star!
We understand that spending One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult. Here are some of the main reasons parents struggle.  Please choose the closest to you.

1 Not enough time
2 My child did not want to spend time with me
3 All my child wanted to do is watch T.V. or play with a gadget
4 My child wanted to do things I felt uncomfortable about
5 My child wanted to do activities that I could not do
6 My child chose a competitive activity. I won and then they got angry
7 My child had a tantrum at the end of One-on-One Time
8 My child wanted to do too many things at once
9 All my children wanted One-on-One Time at the same time
111 Other
999 Prefer not to say
Would you like some new activities to do with your children?
That's okay! You can always type "Play" at anytime if you need an activity. Chat to you later!

We are sorry to hear that you have been having some difficulties spending One-on-One Time with your children. Please type "Help" for other advice that might be of use to you. Thank you for trying your best!

It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. Can you think of a time each day that you can make 5 minutes or a bit more? You can even make household chores into a game to do together. Even 5 minutes can make a big difference!
It can make you feel bad if your children do not want to spend One-on-One Time you. Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? Maybe in the morning or right before bedtime.
Children often to want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Sometimes you might want to give them some other fun options to do instead (Type: "Play" if you want a suggestion).

If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch your child. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!

Competitive games can be challenging for children (and adults!) if they have difficulty losing. You may want to suggest other activities that you can play together instead of against each other (Type "Play" if you want a suggestion").

If your child is very young, it is normal for them to have a short attention span and want to do many things during One-on-One Time. Just accept your child and follow their lead moving from one activity to the next.

You can also find something educational to do together with your child on the gadget. Or maybe ask your child to show you what is their favourite thing to do on the gadget. Just be patient. Soon they may open up to other activities, too!

Sometimes our children will suggest activities that are violent or unsafe. Explain why they can't, and try suggesting alternative activities that would be more appropriate. Type "Play" if you want a suggestion.

You can also just sit next to your child while they are doing something they enjoy (like watching a T.V. show) and show them that you are interested in what they like. If you take their lead they will see that you care.

The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for your child. Try giving your child a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."

It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each one child when you have more than one child. If possible, you can ask another adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one child.
If your child is too young to understand how long a minute is, then you can set a number of time to repeat the activity: "5 more tries and then it will be time for wash our hands before dinner…"
You can also think of times when it would be easier to spend One-on-One Time each child, like later in the evening with an older child after the others have gone to sleep.

Only give the transition warning once. When One-on-One Time is over, thank your child for spending time with you. Then enthusiastically redirect your child to the next activity like washing hands before dinner.

You can also spend One-on-One Time with all of your children at once! 
Type "PLAY" for activities that you can do as a whole family

We are sorry to hear that this has not been helpful. Not all solutions work for everyone. Here are 6 steps that you can try to find a solution by yourself or with someone else:
1. Take a deep breath. Notice how you feel. Then try to focus.
2. Explore the challenge. Think about the perspective/experience of your child? What do they need?
3. Think of possible solutions. What would be the consequence of each solution?
4. Choose a solution 
5. Try it out!
6. Reflect on whether it worked. If it did, hooray! If it did not work, then try another solution.

You should also praise yourself for trying. Parenting is not easy. You are a star just for showing up and caring. You can do it!
Remember, if you ever have any challenges, you can always type "Help" and we will try our best to help you out. Chat to you later!

Pass the Snap  
•	This game is best with at least 3 people
•	Start in a circle and pass one snap around the circle (or clap if you cannot snap)
•	You snap once to throw the snap and once to catch it. Look at the person you are throwing to.  
•	The direction (up, down, straight, curved, rolling the ground) and force (hard, soft, medium) that you throw the snap should affect how the person catches it.  
•	You can bounce the snap, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it.  
•	When everyone gets good at this, you can start moving around the room, still passing the snap.  
•	Can you throw under the leg?  Behind the back?  Through your head?  Intercept a pass? Have fun with the snap!

actions.text:
Hello! This is a stressful time, especially for parents. When we are stressed or angry, we do not make the best decisions. Taking the time to care for ourselves will help us care for our children.
Today's tip is about how keep calm and manage stress in our busy lives.
Would you like some other relaxation activities?
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity to help you relax or reduce stress. Chat to you later!
Hi! How are you doing? If you are feeling overwhelmed or stressed, take a break!  When your children are asleep, do something fun or relaxing for yourself. You deserve it!

Make a list of healthy activities that you like to do. Here are some suggestions:
Listening to your favourite music
Going for a walk (if allowed)
Doing some exercise
Drinking a cup of tea by yourself
Calling up a friend
Singing, dancing, praying, or reading
Sitting in the sun with your eyes closed
Watching your favourite T.V. show
Pick one and do it today!
Would you like some other relaxation activities?
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity to help you relax or reduce stress. Chat to you later!

2 Truths, 1 Lie
•	Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
•	It might help to think of wishes, dreams, likes or dislikes. For example, I hate bananas, I love ice cream and I really wish I could sing. 
•	Say them to your partner or friends. Ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
•	Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
•	Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?

Family Work Out
•	Choose a sport or exercise to do together
•	Decide on a schedule. Are you going to do it every day? For how long? 
•	Try it out for a week. 
•	At the end of the week, ask yourself and your family these questions. How´s it going? How did you feel at the start of the week? How do you feel at the end of the week? What can we do differently next week?

actions.text:
Crazy Chicken
•	Shake your hand in the air 8 times while counting
•	Do it as fast and loud as you can
•	Repeat with your other hand and both feet
•	Do it 7 times, then 6 times until you get to 1.
•	Call out “Crazy chicken” as loud as you can!
•	Have you released all your stress? If not, do it again even faster and louder!

actions.text: Hello! Managing our children's behaviour can be challenging…even in the best of times. We sometimes do not notice when our children are behaving well. But when they are misbehaving, it can be a nightmare!
Today's Tip is all about Child Behaviour. There are 2 main ways that we can do to help our children behave positively more often.
First, we can find ways to encourage our children to behave well more often. Spending One-on-One Time with them is an important first step!
Second, we can learn effective ways to manage difficult behaviours in a loving but firm way.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.
These suggestions are from over 50 years of research on what works. But don't take our word for it, try them out and decide for yourself. And remember...practice makes perfect!
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!
Hi! I just wanted to thank you for making this commitment to improve the life of your children. It shows you really care!

Today's Parenting Tip is all about Praise. How did the above message make you feel? We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
Praise your children when they are behaving well! They may not show it but you’ll see them doing that good behaviour again…
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves! 
Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:
Step 1. Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!
Step 2. Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'
Step 3. Praise with enthusiasm. Really mean it when you say it!

Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Try to find 3 things that you can praise your children for every day. You can also praise other adults in your household, too. Notice how they respond!

*ATTACHMENT*
Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the Sunshine of Positive Attention shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.
Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction
Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!
Let your hand hang by your side. Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you relax your body.
Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out. Repeat 4 times.

Relax your arms and let them swing to the front and back. Take 4 deep breaths while you do this. This is good for your lower back.

Relax your arms and let your arms to swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.

Stop & Listen
• Stop for a moment and close your eyes. 
• How many sounds can you hear? Listen to sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. (Pause for 10 seconds)
• How many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear? 
• Let’s try again. Can you hear any new sounds this time? Can you hear any sounds inside your own body? (Pause for 10 seconds)
• Open your eyes. What new sounds did you hear?

Release Some Energy
•	Baba da bi da ba da baaa! Pause Power! 
•	What’s Pause Power I hear you say? It’s the ability to transform from a grumpy, angry person into a calm, clear one. 
•	When I’m feeling frustrated I plant my feet firmly on the ground and I breathe in and out three times as slowly as I can. Sometimes I imagine I’m smelling a flower and blowing out a candle.

actions.text:
Give Yourself A Hug
•	Bella mama, bella mama hey. 
•	Hey there! How are you feeling today? Do you feel great?!
•	Maybe not. Maybe you shouted again at your children today? Maybe you got angry and said something you don't feel proud of? It’s ok. It’s super stressful right now. 
•	Take a deep breath and think of one thing you did today that you do feel proud of. It doesn't have to be big. And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug. And now think of one thing you did today that you don't feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow? And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug. 
•	Bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama hey”.

Hello! Household rules can help children feel secure and keep them safe from potential dangers both inside the house and in the community. They also help children to know what kind of behaviour is expected from them.
Today's Parenting Tip is about how we can involve our children in creating consistent household rules.
Here is a comic that shows how you can involve your children in establishing household rules.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!

Here are 7 simple tips on how you can make household rules with your children and teens: 
1. Establish household rules when your child is calm and quiet.
2. Involve your child in establishing household rules.
3. Make your household rules clear and specific.
4. Make sure your child understands the reasons why you are establishing a household rule.
5. Make your household rules fair and realistic (just like instructions).
6. Praise and simple incentives can help support your child in following a household rule.
7. Add only 1 household rule at a time.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

Here are some suggestions for household rules that you could establish with your children. Notice that they all describe a positive rule ("Walk inside the house")  instead of a negative one ("Don't run inside the house"). This will make it easier for them to follow!

Here are some suggestions for household rules that you could establish with your teens. Notice that they all describe a positive rule ("Wake up at 8am")  instead of a negative one ("Don't sleep after 8am"). This will make it more likely that they follow it!

Hello! Book-sharing can be a great learning for your child. You can use a simple pictures in books, magazines, or newspapers to do lots of things that you and your child can enjoy.
Press "Y" if you want to learn more about how you can help your child develop through book sharing or "N" if you want to stop this tip.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!

Here are some tips to guide you when you sit down with your child to look at a picture book together:
1. Follow your child's interest
2. Use a lifely voice
3. Pointing and naming
4. Be positive and supportive
5. Making actions and links
6. Talking about feelings
7. Babies and books go well together
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Tooolbox! Shared Reading will help your child to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings

1. Follow your child’s interest
Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest

2. Use a lively voice
Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.

flow.name: Feedbak flow for activity or tip

actions.text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more fun activities to do with your child.

3. Pointing and naming
Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).
If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.

4. Be positive and supportive
Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red apple and says “Tomato”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's an apple!”

5. Making actions and links
Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.

You can use books and stories to help talk with children about topics related to COVID-19 (such as getting sick, not going to school or work, staying indoors, feeling worried) and help them think about how this makes them feel.

6. Talking about feelings
Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.

Here are some examples! 
“Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”
“The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”
“That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”

7. Babies and Books!
Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning.
Hello! A lot of parents struggle when their children have temper tantrums and other demanding behaviours. Today's tip is about how to make this more manageable.
Here is a comic that shows how you can reduce tantrums and other demanding behaviours
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!
Remember that you can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Tech Support".  Chat to you later!

It can be exhausting when your children have too much energy or can't focus on one thing. Sometimes, your children need opportunities to be very active and run around to help them be calm afterwards. 
Type "Y" if you would like suggestions for active and calm things to do with your child.

Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night. 
It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

Help your baby learn through play.  Put objects in your baby’s grasping hand, show them different materials, and answer when they ‘talk’ to you. Type "Y" if you need some ideas of what you can do with your child!

Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.

Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing your baby close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and your baby will get through it together!
Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.

Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!
Type "Y" if you want to learn more.
Babies are much more likely to want to do things if you make the activity fun and playful. Patience is also a must. Take a deep breath if you notice yourself getting frustrated by your baby.

Try to stay calm and support your toddler as they move through the tantrum. Your priority is to ensure that they don’t hurt themselves. Don’t add to your child’s anger by shouting and showing angry emotions. This won’t help.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more.

Your baby or toddler may sometimes want something that they cannot have. If they start whining, first check to see if there is something wrong (are they actually hungry or tired)? If they continue, try to redirect their attention to something else. You should also try to ignore their behaviour while attending to them for comfort and support

1. The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.

actions.text: It‘s hard to feel positive when our kids or teenagers are driving us crazy. We often end up saying “Stop doing that!” But children are much more likely to do what we ask if we give them positive instructions and lots of praise for what they do right.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.
Here are 4 steps to help you get your children to follow your instructions more often:

Step 1. Get Your Child's Attention
Look at your child and say their name when you give your child an instruction. Get down to their level.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!

Step 2. Be Specific, Positive, and Realistic!
Describe exactly what you want your child to do. Say, 'Please wash your hands for 20 seconds before coming to dinner, instead of 'Wash your hands.'
Use positive words when telling your child what to do. Say, ‘Please put your clothes away in the cupboard,’ instead of ‘Don’t make a mess’.
Can your child actually do what you are asking them? It is very hard for a child to keep quiet inside for a whole day but maybe they can keep quiet for 15 minutes.

Step 3. Give Instructions One at a Time
Children are much more likely to do what you ask if you break things up into smaller steps.

Step 4. Praise Your Children When They Follow Instructions
They will feel good about it and be more likely to follow instructions in the future!

Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolkit. In summary…
1. Get their attention
2. Be positive, specific, and realistic
3. One instruction at a time
4. Praise them for doing it! 
It will make a HUGE DIFFERENCE if you can learn these 4 simple steps!

Self-portrait
•	Here’s how your children can draw a picture of themselves!
•	Find a big piece of paper or cardboard. It needs to be the same length or slightly longer than the height of your child
•	Ask your child to lie down on the paper. Carefully draw the outline of your child.
•	Now let your child fill in the outline: face, hair, clothes, shoes, or anything they want!
•	Ask your child to draw things that they like and do not like outside of the outline
•	Have a conversation with your child about these things. You may learn something about your child!
•	You can put their outline up in their room or anywhere in the house – it will make your children feel appreciated!

actions.text: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!

Why do babies cry? 
There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!

Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!

Here are things that you can do when your baby cries:
1. Respond as soon as you can
2. Check to see what is making your baby cry
3. Try swaddling, gently rocking, singing or soft music.
4. Sometimes nothing works though - you are doing your best!
5. If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
6. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic.
Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that there are no bad parents. We are all learning here!

Ship to Shore 
•	A fun active game where children learn different parts of a boat. Everyone must go to the place or activity that you call out
•	“Bow” means run to the front of the boat (room)
•	“Stern” means run to the back of the boat
•	“Starboard” means run to the right side and “Port” means run to the right side
•	“Climb the rigging”: pretend to climb
•	“Clean the deck”: pretend to clean the floor
•	“Lifeboat, [number] people!”: hold hands in a circle with that many people and do knee bends
•	Everyone not in a lifeboat must swim!

actions.text: Close your eyes and think about the day. Name 1 thing that you are grateful for. Name 1 thing that you did well. Name 1 think that you love. You earned a goodnight of sleep!

Hi! How are you feeling right now? Are you feeling stressed and worried? Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful. 
Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready open your eyes again. Everything is okay.
Feel ground beneath you. Feel your body. Bring your awareness to your breath.

Hi there!
At the end of the day, take a minute to think about the day.  
Think about one positive or fun thing you did.
Praise yourself for one thing you did well today.
Think of one thing you can do differently tomorrow. 
Think of one thing that you are grateful for. 
You are a star!

Hi! Here is something fun to help you let go of stress:
Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?
Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.
Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!

Hi! Do you sometimes feel like you are getting everything wrong?
Take a moment to think over the day. Think of one thing you did today that you are proud of.
Wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
Think of one thing you did today that you don’t feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow?
And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
It’s ok. You are doing your best so be kind to yourself. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!
Do your children ever make you feel like screaming? Give yourself a 10-second pause. Breath in and out slowly 5 times. Then try responding in a calmer way. Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.

Hello! Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?
Talk to someone. 
Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. Talk to a tree.
Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment. 
How do you feel now?
A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.

Hi there!
Take a moment to stop what you are doing and connect with your breath.  
What is one thing you can be grateful for right now?
What is one thing that brings you happiness?
What is one thing that you love?
They don't have to be big. Sometimes the small things in life count the most!

Hi there!
Feeling down or desperate? Let’s use the magic power of three. 
Name three sounds you can hear right now.
Name three smells you can smell right now. 
Name your three favourite foods. 
What are three things you can be grateful for right now?
They don’t have to be big.
 At the end of a tough day, thinking of three things to be grateful for can help us find the courage to try again tomorrow.

Hello! Do you feel alone or unsupported? 
Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.
What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t? 
Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.
Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground. 
Try this next time you feel alone or are doing a mundane activity like washing up. It can really help!

Hi! Here is a short relaxation activity for you:
Sit down and close your eyes
How many sounds can you hear? 
Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers.
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?
Try again for another ten seconds. 
Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body?
Notice how you feel now.

Hi! How are you feeling? Do you feel angry or overwhelmed? Use the magic power of three.
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down.

Hello! Are you feeling something so strongly that you want to run away from it?
Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.
It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.
Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?
Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself in this moment?
If your mind starts to wander, it’s normal. Just bring it back to the feeling. Keep breathing and feeling.
Reassure yourself. It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!

Hello! How does your body feel right now? Here's an activity to relax your body:
Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.
Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head. 
Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful? 
Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain. 
Do this for a few breaths. 
Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?
Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!
Thank you for making so much effort to be a better parent. You are loved and appreciated!
There’s no such thing as a perfect parent or the perfect child. We are all just trying our best!
Thank you for getting up every morning and trying again. Even when you are tired. That is real courage and dedication!
Thank you for bringing the sunshine of positive behaviour into your family. Keep shining!
There’s no such thing as a perfect parent. Speak kindly to yourself about what a great job you are doing. We think you’re doing great!
Has anyone told you how incredible you are for being there for your children during a global pandemic? There’s no guidebook for these challenging times but you’re doing it! That makes you amazing.
Thank you for being patient with yourself and your family. Every little bit helps!
Well done for being a man who supports their family. You are a real hero.
You’re a man who puts a lot of thought into everything you do. We see it and appreciate it.
Thank you for your dedication! The world needs more men like you.
Hooray! Other women around the world are cheering for you right now!
It’s not always easy to be a woman in this world. But you are leading the way!
You are such a great example for all men! Keep up the good work.
Your commitment is an inspiration for all men. Keep calm and carry on!
Thank you for your dedication! The world needs more women like you.
Fake it until you make it, Mama!
Thank you for being a superman and being there for your family today! Keep it up!
Hey beautiful woman! Thank you for showing so much strength and sharing it with your family.
Thank you for being an inspiration to other women. Keep shining that light of yours!
Thank you for showing up for your family today and doing your best! You are appreciated!
Well done for getting to the end of the day! Sometimes that’s all we can do. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!
Hooray! Trust that your hard work is bearing sweet fruits, even if you can’t taste them yet!
Sometimes it’s easy, sometimes it’s not. Let go of the mistakes and celebrate the wins, however small!
Every time you take a pause is an act of kindness. Thank you for being kind to yourself and your family today!
It’s the end of the day! You did it! Now it’s time for you. You deserve
Congratulations! You are doing amazing! Remember it’s the small things that make the big difference.
Whatever you feel you did ‘wrong’ today, let it go and try again tomorrow. It’s ok!
You made a difference today by showing up. Your down time starts now!
Well done for trying to figure everything out. Nobody has all the answers but you really do your best!
Taking care of yourself is taking care of your kids! Well done for taking a pause today. Keep it up!
Ten points for you today! Together we can overcome any challenge.
Well done for spending One-on-One time with your family! Time is the most valuable gift you can give them.
Thank you for your kindness and patience today! Even when it’s tough, your words of praise, your smile and your attention are like sunshine for your children.
Your curiosity and creativity are paying off! Give yourself a hug!
Top marks for effort! It’s not easy but you tried your best. That’s all you can ever do!
Happy, sad, angry, excited, worried? Well done for recognizing how you and others felt today! And remember, tomorrow is a brand new day.

2 Truths, 1 Lie
•	Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
•	It might help to think of wishes, dreams, experiences at school, likes or dislikes. For example, I hate bananas, my favourite subject is science, and I really wish I could sing. 
•	Say them to your teenager. Ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
•	Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
•	Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?

All children, including those with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.

Here are 6 simple steps that you can do to support children with disabilities: 
1. Keep your child safe and well
2. Try to understand what they are feeling
3. Communicate and talk with them
4. Praise them!
5. Make things that you do the same every day to help them feel secure
6. Ask for help if you can
Type "Y" if you would like to learn more or "N" to end this tip.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please answer with either Yes or No

Step 1. Keep your child safe and well 
• Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
• Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see

That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to support children with disabilities.
Here is a link to disability services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]
Chat later!

Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling
• Your child may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.
• Tell them that you love them
• Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!

Step 3. Talking and communicating with your child
• Get down to your child’s level when you speak. 
• Look at them and smile
• Give them time to tell you or show you what they think
• Tell your child that you understand
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

Step 4. Praise them!
• Praise them for behaving well, and for trying. 
• Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.
• Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!

That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more. 
Here is a link to disability services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]
Chat to you later!

Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure
• Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.
• Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.
• Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.

• Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
• Use simple language and clear instructions. If words aren't good for them, try gestures and pictures.

Step 6. Ask for help if you can
• Share the load with other adult family members.
•  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.

• Share your challenges AND your successes.
• It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.
• Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!

Sometimes we feel frustrated with our children because we expect them to behave in ways that they are not yet developmentally ready for.
Learning about child development means we can have realistic expectations and also to spot any problems with their growth and development.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.
All children develop at different rates. But there are some things that we expect children to be able to do at an age. These are called ‘development’ milestones.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about child development.

If you are concerned that your child might be delayed in their development, here is a link to services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

You can also visit UNICEF's website for more helpful information about child development [INSERT LOCAL UNICEF LINK]
Chat to you later!
Many things affect our children's development. For example, development is helped by eating healthy food, having immunisations, and parents or caregivers who talk to them a lot.
To learn more about child development milestones, type 1 for babies (0-2 years), 2 for young children (2-9 years), and 3 for teens (10-17 years).
Sorry I don't understand what you mean. Please type 1 for babies (0-2 years), 2 for young children (2-9 years), and 3 for teens (10-17 years).

Infant (0–1 year) needs:
• Us to provide food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety.
• A strong bond with parent/ caregiver.
• Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!

Toddlers (2-3 years):
• Become a curious little explorer - watch out for climbing! 
• Learn through play and trying things out
• Want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions.
• Want your praise and your approval

Young teenagers (10-12 years)
• More interested in learning in school.
• Start to want independence and trust.
• Want to spend time with other children and young teenagers.
• May be interested in religion or spirituality

Infants (0-1):
• 0–6 months: Smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.
• 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened. 
• 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!

Toddlers (2-3 years):
• Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.
• Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.
• May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.

Young teenagers (10-12 years)
• May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.
• Can be very self-conscious and sensitive
• Can learn to better manage anger and tolerate frustration.

Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
• Begin to challenge adult rules
• Are often insecure and confused.
• Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings
• Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.

Young children (4-6 years):
• Same as toddlers, but also...
• Learn through actions and play.
• Develop friendships with other children
• Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!

Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
• Their friends are important and affect their choices
• Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change
• Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities

Young children (4-6 years):
• May talk a lot; ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more
• Does not like to lose, share or take turns, but losing and taking turns can be taught.

Older teenagers (15 – 19 years)
• The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!
• Your child is almost an adult, they are able to communicate with you about
almost anything.
• They can think about new ideas, develop their own ideals and set their
own course.

Older children (7-9 years)
• Same early childhood, but also…
• Interested in learning at school.
• Starts to want independence and trust.
• Wants to spend time with other children.

Older teenagers (15 – 19 years)
• They are forming their own identity and have a growing sense of their
sexuality
• They may prefer being with peers more than with you
• They may show risk-taking behaviours, frequent mood swings, and rebellious
attitudes. They can also have exciting new ideas!

Older children (7-9 years)
• May start to ask questions about religion
• May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.
• Can be very self-conscious and sensitive. May be very active. By now they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.

The most important things that you can do for your teen in this stage are:
• Continue providing love, support and guidance and build a strong
parent-child connection
• Monitor who their friends are, have clear rules to keep them safe
• Nurture their independence

• Be patient and accepting of the person they are becoming - even if it is not what you had imagined
• Encourage them to begin to take responsibility for the future
• Keep supporting them and loving them so that they feel comfortable, secure, and safe
Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Knowing about child development can help you feel less frustrated by them.

If you are concerned that your child might be delayed in their development, here is a link to services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

You can also visit UNICEF's website for more helpful information about child development [INSERT LOCAL UNICEF LINK]

actions.text: Hello! How are you feeling? If you are feeling overwhelmed or stressed, here is a short activity that can help when you are feeling like needing some more support to get through the day.

Recognise what is happening for you in this moment. What are you thinking? Are your thoughts positive or negative. How do you feel? Do you feel pleasant or unpleasant? How does your body feel? Do you feel tense or relaxed?
Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. You can then say the following words silently to yourself:

May I be happy.
May there be love in my family.
May I feel loved.

May I be peaceful.
May I be safe.
May I be healthy.
Before you open your eyes, take a moment to reflect on your experience. Notice if you feel any different.

Here is a link other support that may help you cope with any stress or other emotional difficulties that you may be experiencing. If you ever need this link, type "Help". Chat to you later!
*Referral to local mental health services hotline in country*

A Short Pause
•	Sit down and close your eyes
•	Listen to your breath as it goes in and out. 
•	Notice how you feel. 
•	Take a few more deep breaths.
•	When you are ready open your eyes again. Do you feel any different? 
•	Remind yourself that “Everything is ok”

Stop the river at the source. The same things usually make us get stressed and angry every time. What makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?
Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.
Here are some things that can help make it less likely that bad things happen when you are angry:

Can’t go to work? Schools closed? Worried about money? It is normal to feel stressed and overwhelmed.
School shutdown is also a chance to make better relationships with our children and teenagers. One-on-One time is free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and shows them that they are important.

picture

First of all remember to set aside time to spend with each child.
It can be for just 20 minutes, or longer – it’s up to us. It can be at the same time each day so children or teenagers can look forward to it.
Switch off the TV and phone. This is virus-free time!
Would you like to receive the tips about one-on-one time with your children now?

Here are some ideas with your baby:
* Copy their facial expression and sounds
* Sing songs, make music with pots and spoons
* Stack cups or blocks
* Tell a story, read a book, or share pictures

Here are some ideas with your child:
* Read a book or look at pictures
* Go for a walk – outdoors or around the home
* Dance to music or sing songs!
* Do a chore together –  make cleaning and cooking a game!
* Help with school work

Here are some ideas with your teenager:
* Talk about something they like: sports,  music, celebrities, friends
* Go for a walk – outdoors or around the home
* Exercise together to their favorite music
Remember to listen to your children, look at them. Give them your full attention. Have fun!

It is also important to ask your child what they would like to do:
choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t OK with physical distancing, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.

actions.text: Hello @contact.name! Keeping your family healthy and safe from COVID-19 can feel even harder when you live in crowded conditions. There are things you can do to make this easier for your family.
Here are some tips for you.

quick_replies: Help your children with physical distancing
actions.text: Tap on any of the buttons below to discover more about that topic. Tap on the "Exit" button if you want quit.

* Limit those leaving and returning to your immediate living space to as few and as infrequent as possible
* Only leave your household or area for essential reasons like getting food or medical attention

* Explain to your children that they have an important job of keeping themselves and their community healthy by temporarily physically distancing from others
* Show them extra positive attention when they make an effort to practice safe physical distancing from others

* It might be hard to find soap and water, but practicing good hygiene is more important now than ever
* Try to wash all family members’ hands as often as possible
* Let children teach each other how to wash their hands
* Encourage children to avoid touching their face

* Looking after children and other family members is difficult in cramped spaces, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared
* Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
* Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household
* It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break

* You might not have space to yourself to deal with all the stress and emotions you are feeling 
* Notice when you are feeling stressed or upset and take a pause...even three deep breaths can make a difference!

* Encourage children to think of activities they can do to exercise while avoiding contact with who do not live already in your immediate space
* Jumping activities, dancing or running in circles can be fun!
Would you like to receive more tips?

Well done @contact.name!

Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet during COVID-19. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money with our children is important. Our children can also help us to spend and save that will benefit the family.

Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

Making a budget with your children and teens.
A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times. It can also help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.
Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

Here are 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money with your children:
Step 1: What do we spend on now?
• Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
• Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
• Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
• Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

Here are 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money:
Step 1: What do we spend on now?
• Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
• Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
• Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
• Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

Step 3: Build your own budget
• Find a bag of stones or anything with lots of bits. This is your money for the month.
• As a family, decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones on your picture.
